treatment_steps.title: Isolate the affected plant immediately
treatment_steps.description: Move the plant at least 3 feet away from other plants to prevent spore transmission through air currents or water splash.

treatment_steps.title: Remove infected tissue
treatment_steps.description: Using sterilized scissors (70% isopropyl alcohol), cut off leaves with spots at the base. Remove any leaf with >30% damage. Sterilize tools between each cut.

treatment_steps.title: Apply copper-based fungicide
treatment_steps.description: Spray all remaining leaves with copper hydroxide solution (0.5-1% concentration as per product label). Ensure coverage on both top and bottom leaf surfaces. Apply in early morning or late evening when temperature is below 85°F (29°C).

treatment_steps.title: Improve environmental conditions
treatment_steps.description: Increase spacing between plants to 12+ inches. Ensure good air circulation (use a fan if indoors). Water only at soil level in early morning. Remove water trays from under pots.
materials_needed: Optional: small fan for indoor plants

treatment_steps.title: Monitor and document progress
treatment_steps.description: Inspect all leaves weekly for new spots. Photograph leaves to track progression. Continue copper spray applications as scheduled even if symptoms improve.

dosage_frequency: Copper fungicide spray: Apply every 7-10 days for 3 consecutive applications. Then apply monthly during active growing season (spring-summer) as preventive measure. Do not exceed 6 applications per season.
safety_warnings: ALWAYS wear protective eyewear and gloves when handling and applying fungicides
DO NOT apply copper compounds when temperature exceeds 85°F (29°C) - risk of leaf burn
Copper is HIGHLY TOXIC to aquatic organisms - keep away from waterways, ponds, and drains
Dispose of diseased plant material in sealed plastic bags with household trash - NEVER compost
Wash hands thoroughly with soap after handling diseased plants or fungicides
Keep fungicides out of reach of children and pets
If fungicide contacts eyes or skin, rinse immediately with water for 15 minutes and seek medical attention
when_to_consult_expert: Spots continue to spread after 3 weeks of treatment
More than 50% of the plant shows symptoms
Multiple plants in your collection develop symptoms simultaneously
You are unsure whether the infection is fungal, bacterial, or viral
Plant shows additional symptoms: wilting, rot, or severe discoloration beyond leaf spots
You have concerns about safe fungicide application
Symptoms return within 2 months after successful treatment

citations.title: Management of Fungal Leaf Spot Diseases in Succulent Plants
citations.key_findings: Copper-based fungicides showed 85-92% efficacy against Alternaria and Cercospora species on Aloe. Early application at first symptom appearance critical for success.

citations.title: Environmental Factors Influencing Fungal Leaf Pathogens of Aloe Species
citations.key_findings: High humidity (>70%) and leaf wetness duration >6 hours significantly increase infection rates. Air circulation reduces infection by 60%.

citations.title: Copper Fungicides: Application Best Practices for Ornamental Succulents
citations.source: HortTechnology, American Society for Horticultural Science
citations.key_findings: Application timing and temperature critical. Phytotoxicity observed above 85°F. Three applications at 7-day intervals provide season-long protection.

evidence_level: High - Based on peer-reviewed research and field trials
